awd_abstract_narration:
The past two decades have witnessed an explosion in the scale and complexity of data sets that arise in science and engineering. Broadly, clustering methods which discover latent structure in data are our primary tool for navigating, exploring and visualizing massive datasets. These methods have been widely and successfully applied in phylogeny, medicine, psychiatry, archaeology and anthropology, phytosociology, economics and several other fields. Despite its ubiquity, the widespread scientific adoption of clustering methods have been hindered by the lack of flexible clustering methods for high-dimensional datasets and by the dearth of meaningful inferential guarantees in clustering problems. Accordingly, the goal of this research is to develop new and effective methods for clustering complex data-sets, and to further develop an inferential grounding -- which will in turn lead to actionable conclusions -- for these methods. This research will lead to the development of new clustering methods, as well as to a deeper understanding of the fundamental limitations of methods aimed at uncovering latent structure in data. 

The research component of this project consists of four aims designed to address related aspects of this high-level goal: (a) analyze and develop new clustering methods for high-dimensional datasets, with a particular focus on practically useful methods like mixture-model based clustering, and minimum volume clustering; (b) develop novel methods for inference in the context of clustering, motivated by scientific applications where it is important not only to cluster the data but also to clearly characterize the sampling variability of the discovered clusters; (c) develop fundamental lower bounds for high-dimensional clustering (d) develop novel methods for clustering functional data with inferential guarantees. These research components are closely coupled with concrete educational initiatives, including the development and broad dissemination of publicly-available software for high-dimensional clustering; tutorials and workshops at Machine Learning conferences and fostering further interactions between the Departments of Statistics and Machine Learning at Carnegie Mellon.

por.por_cntn:
This research grant focused on addressing challenges that hinder the widespread scientific use of clustering methods ? the dearth of associated methods for rigorous statistical inference. Methods for inference broadly allow us to quantify uncertainty, to discern ?true? clusters from finite-sample artifacts, as well as to rigorously test hypotheses related to the estimated cluster structure. Our research made fundamental contributions to our understanding of inferential methods for clustering along multiple fronts. 

Our research developed some of the first practical methods for hypothesis testing and uncertainty quantification in mixture models, and more broadly in irregular statistical models. Our research also developed connections between two classes of clustering algorithms ? spectral algorithms and density level-set clustering algorithms ? showing that spectral algorithms can consistently recover certain well-conditioned level-set clusters, and conversely that it can fail to consistently recover ill-conditioned level-set clusters (no matter how large the sample-size).  Finally, our research further developed our understanding of non-parametric hypothesis testing, developing a comprehensive geometric picture of the intrinsic difficulty of this task, showing remarkable adaptivity properties of popular chi-squared type tests, and developing practical and studying general-purpose methods to rigorously calibrate these tests.

Our work on clustering, on local minimax testing, on conditional independence testing, on the permutation method, and on developing assumption-light inferential tools have already stimulated significant follow-up work by several other research groups across disciplines (theoretical computer science, statistics, machine learning, information theory and biostatistics). Our research findings have been published, and have been presented, across venues in these communities. The assumption-light inferential tools we developed through this grant have already been applied by researchers in causal inference, in algebraic statistics, and in the analysis of microbiome data. We also hope that these methods will see continued adoption by the broader research community.

The grant also supported the dissemination of these results (via multiple high-impact publications and numerous conference and workshop presentations). The grant also supported the training of multiple graduate students, who now occupy prestigious postdoctoral positions and faculty positions at universities across the world (e.g., Stanford University, University of Cambridge and Yonsei University).
